bibl.title: Letter from George K. Strode to Philip Showalter Hench, June 6, 1947

div1.p: Strode informs Hench that Sawyer has retired from the Rockefeller Foundation, but that he has forwarded Hench's letter to him. Strode doubts that the Foundation would financially support the Camp Lazear memorial, although he finds the idea intriguing.

div1.head: Letter from George K. Strode to Philip Showalter Hench, June 6, 1947
div1.opener:
THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
INTERNATIONAL HEALTH DIVISION
49 WEST 49th STREET, NEW YORK 20
CABLE ADDRESS: ROCKFOUND, NEW YORK
June 6, 1947
EXECUTIVE OFFICERS
DIRECTOR
DR. GEORGE K. STRODE
ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR
DR. ANDREW J. WARREN
ASSISTANT DIRECTOR
DR. HUGH H. SMITH
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I must apologize for failure to have acknowledged
earlier your May 12th letter which was addressed to Dr. Sawyer,
but sent to this office. Dr. Sawyer's present address is:
3927 Idaho Avenue, N.W.
Washington, D. C.
He retired from The Rockefeller Foundation in 1944, and has
been living in Washington since then.

It seems appropriate for me to send your communica-
tion on to him, and I am so doing. My regret is that it has
taken so many days to do this. I have to confess that the letter
got misplaced in my own office and turned up by accident only
this morning.

In regard to the point you raise of possible Rockefeller
Foundation interest in the Memorial described, I must give my
honest opinion which is that I see little likelihood of monetary
support. I say this despite the fact that I think the idea is
intriguing.
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, George K. Strode Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester
Minnesota
